So I'm out $12 in shipping for the joy of holding this nice looking piece if junk.Overall I will never purchase from mobilecityonline again!Merry Christmas!

Originally ordered this item in late July.  First one shipped was defective (wouldn't take a charge).  Returned for replacement, which wasn't sent until shipper received defective item back.  Second item was also defective - same problem.  I requested prepaid shipping and asked that a replacement be sent right away.  The initial shipping charge was refunded, but it's ten days later and I still don't have the item.Can't evaluate the product yet, but getting a hold of it has been a nightmare!

I was looking for an inexpensive, lightweight wireless solution for my office phone.  Cardo Wireless makes a device called the BTA-II that adapts a standard cel phone with 2.5mm headphone jack to Bluetooth.  Radio Shack sells an adapter from a standard corded land line phone to a 2.5mm headphone jack.  The combination of those two products gave my office phone Bluetooth capability.  However when I tried my Motorola H500 headset, the audio reception was perfect, but the callers heard a loud buzzing noise.  I tried everything and couldn't get the buzzing to go away.  I was about to give up, but then decided that maybe I should try a better headset.  I bought the Scala 700, and was immediately impressed with the improved comfort and sound quality.  The buzzing to callers was no longer there.  In fact, folks that I called commented that the sound quality was excellent.  Now I have the perfect cordless office solution using a comfortable Bluetooth headset, the Cardo Scala 700.
summary: Cardo Scala 700 works with my office phone!

reviewText: This was my first time purchasing a hands-free device for my cell phone. I did a lot of research and looked at different headsets online as well as asked others what they use.  I have been very pleased with my choice of the Cardo Scala 700.  It's very easy to use and the sound quality is excellent. The size of this headset is ideal, not too big.
I bought this for the "find me" feature.  It didn't work.  Wrote the company.  Never heard from them.

The reception and the functionality of the Scala 700 Bluetooth Headset is quite good, taking into consideration the relatively low cost.  The actual earpiece is a bit problematic in that it does not fit securely on your ear, however, it can be adjusted for a better fit.  Overall, I am pleased with the headset.

the product does not work with the Treo 700 phone.  I have friends with the Treo 650 that use the Cardo 500 model and it works fine. I actually borrowed someones Cardo 500 and it works withmy Treo 700 just fine.  Can you help me with this problem?

I search all the net to find the best review on the lowest priced bluetooth headset I could find.  Out of all the ones researched, I decided to purchase the Scala 700.  I got it quickly in the mail.  It only takes very little time to charge and the charge lasts for days and days...I love this lightweight device and do recommend it to anyone.  I can hear on it very well and have no complaints from the people listening to me on the other end.
summary: Scala 700 a great value to have

reviewText: I can talk for over 5 continuous hours on this headset (never tried longer).  However, my Motorola HS820 is more comfortable AND my callers understand me better.  I get many complaints with the Scala 700 that my voice isn't clear or our connection is bad.  In addition, when I listen to mp3 files, the HS820 has a warmer sound.  The Scala 700 has a 'tinty' sound.The Scala 700 comes with a proprietary usb and a case.  Nice.

I bught one of these, and the tiny plastic earpiece broke the first time I tried to adjust it. I sent it back and received a new one. I am not sure why so many people complain that it is uncomfortable, I barely even notice it is there. It also paired pretty quickly and easily with my LG VX 8500 (Chocolate phone). The sound quality on my end is very good, but some people I have called complain of an echo on their end and it picks up a lot of ambient noise. I have not tried pairing with multiple phones, using it in a windy environment, or using the feature to find it when it is lost. I did try the voice command dialing, and it works intermittently. I cannot say that I am very impressed with this headset, although it is convenient, I would definitely not buy another one.
summary: My first Bluetooth headset, but not impressed

reviewText: When I purchased my Palm Treo 700p last August (2006), I got a Motorola H500 headset with it.  But listeners frequently complained about the quality, so I stopped using it.  Then, doing some web research, I discovered the Cardo Scala 700, which I then purchased in November.  (It had just replaced the Scala 500.)  It's been my constant companion ever since (6 months how).Once I got the ear hook shaped right, it is quite comfortable - often I'm not even aware it's on.  I've experimented with switching back and fort from the Cardo to my Treo mic, and listeners say there's no discernable difference.  At first there were some minor difficulties getting it linked, but after the first few weeks it and my Treo have become fast friends.  Also, the look is quite 'cute' - and not as bulky or boxy as many which are sprouting from people's heads these days.I was a little bothered by the slight "rattle" of the black face cover (also a button), but a miniscule drop (from a sharp toothpick end) of some glue (I used Gorilla Glue) at the 'point' fixed that problem.I'll notice some static when my Treo and my Cardo aren't well alighed (like when my body is between them) - but the problem is minimal, and my listeners claim they can't hear any interference.  It seems to carry a lot of charge - I've never had it run out on me, and the recharge time each evening seems quite minimal.It has many more functions than I commonly use.  I primariliy use off and on, and turn off the blue flashing light.  I've never been comfortable with that cyborg head flashing blue light look.  Once in awhile I'll press the button that does last number re-dial, with sometimes embarassing results.My favorite use of it is when driving.  I can do a quick look down at my Treo and see who's calling, and then just talk away when the call arrives - hands free.  It's gotten to the point where I get irritated with myself when I have to hold my Treo to my ear!  Though after I've received a call, I can put the Cardo on, and press the button that turns it on - seamlessly in the middle of a conversation.  Obvioiusly my Cardo has spoiled me!  I've not paid any attention to subsequent Bluetooth headsset ads - because I'm quite content with what I have.
summary: Very satisfied - for use with my Palm Treo 700p

reviewText: While this product was easy to sync up, my first minute of conversation with it contained a lot of 'what?' for the other party.  I actually returned it and will continue with my wired ear piece.

This review is for the Scala 700, but I have also used the Scala 500, and so, I will point out some of the differences between the two.Both models are compatible and work well with my Palm Treo 650 from Sprint (firmware version 1.13a). The Bluetooth pairing is fast and easy, and I have not ever lost that pairing. The headset picks up audio of incoming/outgoing calls quickly. I have not experienced any missed calls.The Scala 700 works as equally well as the Scala 500 with the Treo 650. However, I prefer the Scala 700 for the following reasons. (1) The Scala 700 is noticeably smaller than the Scala 500. (2) You can disable the blinking light on the Scala 700 if you don't like it. (3) You can press a button on the 700 to indicate the amount of battery power remaining: high, medium, or low. (4) The Scala 700 comes with 2 cables for charging (the usual wall plug cable, as well as a USB cable for charging off a computer/laptop). (5) Using your phone's volume control, you can get the Scala 700 to buzz, in the event you've misplaced it.  (6) While I have no use for it, this headset can be paired with up to 8 different phones.  Handy if you intend to share it with others.Some other reviewers have complained about the ear loop not feeling comfortable. I have not found that to be true. In fact, I prefer the ear loop that comes with the Scala 700, because I can shape it to contour my ear more closely.Additionally, I can't complain about the sound quality of this headset. I've asked a few of my callers how I sound, and all have said that I sound clear. While driving my car at highway speeds (with windows closed, radio turned off), callers could hear some background noise but indicated it was minimal. All callers said that I sounded clear and audible.  I should point out that I have not tested the headset in windy conditions. But that's not of concern to me, as it will be used primarily for use while driving.Occasionally, I'll notice some audible interference (static or click sounds) on the headset. I haven't determined any specific cause for it, but it always disappeared as quickly as it came.  And it doesn't come often.Lastly, this headset has a voice dial feature, but the Treo 650 does not support voice dial with Bluetooth headsets. Even though you may see references to "Voice Tags" in the Treo's preferences screen and user manual, voice dialing is only supported when using a specific brand of hands-free car kit.
summary: Works great with the Palm Treo 650

reviewText: I love silicon covers for my electronic devices. They provide a little extra protection so that just in case it slips from my hand or purse, it won't shatter. More importantly (for me) they keep the phone from slipping off of smooth surfaces -- or out of my hand -- in the first place. This one isn't quite as slip-proof as others I have, but the price was unbelievably affordable for this one (most sell for $12-15). Well worth it!

It completely covers the light sensor, so my phone thinks that its in a dark room all the time. Worst of all, the darn thing ripped the first time I put it on the phone. The only hole that seemed to line up was the one for the camera. If it wasn't for that, I would have sent it back. reviewText: This was the easiest headset by far to setup and use. I'm using it with a Motorola Razr V3. I had owned a Planetronics unit, that felt 'heavy' on my ear. The HS815 even after several hours of use still feels light. And the audio quality is good. I would reccomend this unit.

Well, the price seemed right. But little did I suspect that those on the other end would have such a hard time hearing me. It is so bad, it almost feels rude to use it when making calls. Fortunately, the Plantronics Voyager 510 was on sale right after I bought the HS815 and, having seen it's near perfect reviews, decided I'd get it for our other phone and compare. In short: there is no comparison. The Voyager seems of higher quality before you even turn it on. The sound is superior on my end (though the HS815 is satisfactory in this area), and unlike the HS815, those I am speaking with do not know I am using a headset. I'll be looking to buy another Voyager as soon as it goes back on sale. As for the HS815, I should have read the reviews more closely before buying. Not worth the poor performance...at any price.

I have a 3 month old Motorola Razor phone, and I just bought this bluetooth earpiece. No matter what ringtone you have chosen on your phone, when you have the bluetooth turned on, it only rings with 1 type of ring.In other words, I can choose the "Cingular" tune for my phone to use for it's ring tone. BUT if I have the bluetooth headset turned on, and I get a phone call, it rings with a generic ring tone (called "continental"). It is a loud obnoxious generic ringtone.After speaking to Cingular customer service, and speaking to Motorola customer service, APPARENTLY there is no way to change the ringtone to anything other than 'continental' when the bluetooth is on.Folks, DO NOT waste your money downloading ringtones from the internet, because they won't work anyway if y ou use bluetooth.And don't waste your money on any motoroloa bluetooth headpieces if you want to have a different ringtone than 'continental'!The funny thing is, I have several friends that have motorola phones and motorola bluetooth earpieces that don't have this issue, but when I told the Motorola customer support about that, they don't seem to care and tell me it shouldn't work that way and it's not supported with anything other than Continental ringtone. Ok fine.Apparently the R&D; department at Motorola has used their profits towards other things than improving their products. I will be purchasing a new wireless earpiece soon, and you can bet it won't be motorola.I just wanted to get the word out there for others to be aware.
summary: Good luck if you want to customize your ring tone

reviewText: I got it yesterday & It took me just few minutes to get started. Once configured, it is just a press of a button to get going.The voice is clear, the range is great. I can roam around in my house & office without the cell phone in my hand & still get great reception with my ne Motorola 815(within 10 meters). I like the desgn, the mouth piece is closer to your mouth. enabling better reception to the other guy. You can never get such a product for such alow price. I think, it is a good deal.We need to check the battery life (talk time & stand by).
The product works good...pairs and connects very easily. However, I found the battery life to be much lessar than the other bluetoooth head sets I have.
summary: Good functionally but low battery life

reviewText: This headset attracted to me because of the Motorola name and it has not failed me yet.  Charging does not take long, for what I use of it, it does last me for days but then again, I am not one who lives on the cellphone either.  It is quite lightweight which is a major plus and the sound is quite good, even my wife hears me mumble under my breathe when speaking to her =(  so the mike is quite sensitive especially in quieter environments.

I tried pairing this without reading the manual. RTFM. Press and hold the chrome-talk button until the blue light is continuously lit and then pair it with your phone.It works well with Palm Treo 700p. It looks great. You can hear the voices loud and clear. It has volume control. This headset is feature rich.The microphone sucks big time. Have to talk loud for the other person to hear properly. The volume button is a cheapo plastic thingy and I'm afraid that it'll fall off some day. Whoever thought of making the microphone point more towards the eye than the mouth should be slapped.Not the best. But works ok for the 25 bucks..
Knowing that I have a car charger, is huge....I always forget to check if I need to charge my phone.....now that I have this charger, I never have to worry about how many bars are left.....
This charger works well so far,  and is also as compact as the original.  We are also happy with the price.
summary: the charger seems to work well so far and is almost as compact as my original.

reviewText: You may want to reconsider ordering this one. Its not an LG brand charger and it dosen't even fit for the VX8300 phone. Shipping cost was over $5.00and its not even as advertised. Not happy at all with Bargin Cell product. Its a waste of money.
summary: Not an LG brand charger at all!!!!!!!!!!!

reviewText: Bought this for my phone but it often falls out of the source in my car and does not seem to charge very well  but only use it in emergencies anyway.

This item is no longer available through Verizon as the phone is old.  But, I, my husband, and lots of other people still use these phone.  I was delighted to find this car charger after searching locally and on the internet and was about to give up hope.  I had ordered a generic one before this one and it did not perform well.  This one has been ideal.  Received it fast, it looks great and works great.  Price was very fair too.
summary: Verizon LG Rapid Car Charger for Cell Phone

reviewText: this charger was for my old phone from high school. i recently broke my droid so i had to get a cheap phone until my contract expired. i bought the phone and then this charger online, it didn't give me any problems. it works just like i thought it would. the thing i dont like about it is what the tip that connects your phone is made of plastic, i had a problem with my old copy. the plastic tip break if your phone happens to sway back and forth. so you have to keep your phone on the chair or something flat. you can't allow your phone to bend at the charger or else it will break.

...and I don't have to suddenly remember when I'm on the road, "Oh no -- I forgot to refresh the battery before I left home! What'm I gonna do if I have a problem?!"It arrived pretty much when I was told it would, and works great.Thank you!
summary: Finally I Can Charge My CellPhone While I'm Driving:)

reviewText: Bought to replace one that my husband had with a broken wire. Now he can charge his phone without sitting the charger and phone at a certain angle and hoping he doesn't hit a bump in the road.
CHARGER WORKS GREAT. CHARGES PHONE AS EXPECTED.SHIPPED QUICKLY AND ARRIVED INTACT.I FORGOT TO ORDER TWO, SO I WOULD HAVE ONE FOR MY OTHER CAR.

I thought I was buying a REAL Verizon LG charger. What I got was something that belongs in a dollar store. It works but but you have to keep playing with the cigarette lighter plug to keep it powered up. Stay away from this one.
The product provides excellent value.  Price was right and the product functions very well, enabling long calls on multiple day trips.
summary: VS8300 Rapid Car Charger with IC chip

reviewText: Works fine in my wife's car. Her LG VX 8300 phone has outlasted 2 other chargers. They seem to last about 1-2 years before the cord is damaged.  This cord seems as good as the others.
We appreciate the quality and the rapidity of its arrival.  We have not needed to use it much, but it has worked well.
The Verizon LG VX8300 weak point is the charge port. So Chargers have to be replaced when some wear is detected. Happy to fined replacement chargers.
Does not fit in car socket snugly enough. Socket? New car and I tried them all. Also, I hate needing to put a certain amount of words here.
Just what I needed for my "dinosaur" flip phone at an unbelievably great price.  Thank goodness you can still find things like this on Amazon.
Had to replace my charger cord for the vehicle; could not buy one from the Verizon store and had to order it online.  Product came quickly with no hassles, and works just fine.
This charger worked well to keep an old phone charged in the car. Was cheap and shipped quickly too so I cant complain
Does not fit a verizon LG VX8300.  Don't waste your time and money.  Junk. Very disappointed with both products. Order elsewhere.
This product is fine for car recharging - especially for $1.I bought 2  - the second one broke soon at the stem. Not sure if the $39 model would have been as fragile with rough handling.
The number on the phone matched the LG model on the charger exactly, but the charger does not fit the phone.
worked well for me buy it hope it works for you bang for the buck so if you need one buy it.
This product is meeting my needs and came in 2 days! Perfect for me! :))Its just what I needed!Thanks!
Car charger did not fit for LG 8300.  The neck was not long enough to fit into the cigarette lighter.  Please advise return details/process.  Thank you.

This is the third charger for this phone.  The connectors on the older phones are bulky and break too easily when torqued.  The phone is still going strong so will continue to buy chargers for it until it finally dies
summary: Older style cell phone still in use

reviewText: I was a little disappointed with the quality of this product, which was probably made in China. I think we need to get back to the kind of quality we were used to in our country years ago.  I will use it but am not that pleased with it.
This was a cheap fix to a need that endced up being a waste of time and the shipping cost.  It worked one day.  Ended up buying another at the Verizon store for $25.95 but at least it works.
i never give a 5 or a one because things can always be better and worse. it does the job it is supposed to do.
It said it would fit the phone we have, but it doesn't.  We have the VX5300 phone, it wouldn't fit.

I have had my old clam phone for a long time now and never bought a car charger........so after about 8 yrs......I have it.....works just fine....Glad I could find it.....shipping was fast for which I was glad....thank you
ok for shock protection, but here are the cons:1. Crappy looking.2. Can't see the keypad once you put the glove on.3. No protection for the screen.

It covers all the buttons on the keypad, protecting them from dust, moisture and from being read and used.  A pain to put on and remove.  Useless design.  Mic hole way to small to be heard properly.  I had to cut the keypad section off and use the perimeter for phone cushioning.  A full leather case is a better investment.
summary: How can you dial the phone with this thing on?

reviewText: The leather pouch is really great. My only issue would be that it kind of stained the phone a little bit, which is not really a great deal, or hasn't happened before with other leather pouches for cell phones in the past. It really has allowed me to keep my cell phone with me all the time, safely and with access to all the features.Excellent product.

I wish I had not purchased this item.  The belt clip swivels, but is not removable, you must unclip it in order to use the Q.  There are no cut-outs for the mic, earpiece and speakers, so it is next to impossible to use the Q while it is in the case.  I'm not happy with this case.
Overall it's just what I wanted.  It's hard to put the Q phone in the pouch with the extended batters.  But I knew the pouch wasn't for that.  But you can do it.  It's a tight squeeze.

Overall, it does what I want. As mentioned before, it is difficult to put the Q phone in the pouch with the extended battery, or even the regular battery for that matter. It does cover up the quick buttons on the bottom row of the phone, so it's not as usable as I would have liked.

The description says, "Replacement Styli" However you get only ONE (1) stylus with this product. Is that a good value for $10 (after shipping)? No. To add insult to injury, the replacement stylus does NOT fit well at all. The original Palm stylus fits so that the end is perfectly flush to the Treo case; this one sticks out. The stylus itself is lightweight and cheap-feeling. After using this stylus the orginal will fit looser in the Treo. The only positive I can say is that it did work when I tried to scribble on paper with the hidden pen. Steer clear of this product and go with the genuine Palm replacementr pens, which come in a three-pack.
I wish I'd ordered a cheaper version.  This model is too tight a fit for my Verizon Treo 650. I have to leave it partially out of it's holder; otherwise, it's a struggle to pull it out to use.
summary: OK, but not worth the money

reviewText: Don't bother with this pen-based styli.  It does not fit properly in the Treo 650, sticking out a bit.  The pen is just inserted in the hollow tube top of the styli - no catch to hold it on, just friction.  As a result, the stylus would sometimes come out with the pen still inside the Treo.  The pen shook out easily, but this was a hassle.The pen is too tiny to be useful anyway.  Get a regular replacement styli instead and skip this one.  In the end, mine broke after just a few months. Since the stylus did not properly fit the Treo (too tall), after a while the plastic top broke off.
summary: Does not properly fit Treo, flimsy and broke within 2 months

reviewText: Save your money and your time and get the real one. This is a cheap knockoff.
the Motorola HS815 Bluetooth Wireless Headset - Blue/Siver, is just a little bit heavy but have a good transference of sound, and it is listened to strong.

Like others, I bought this headset because it's a Motorola, and I figured it'd worked beautifully with my (Cingular) Moto Razr.  (I actually bought two, one for me and one for my wife; we have the same Razr phone.)  Was I disappointed!  The biggest problem is that the phone doesn't know to automatically hook up with the headset when they are both near each other, even after I've paired them.  So each time I want to use the headset, I have to dig through my phone's menu to establish the connection.  This is a royal pain.  What's more, it's almost never clear whether the headset is 'on' such that the phone can recognize it.  About 25% of the time, even when I've turned on the headset (hold button down 5 seconds), the phone doesn't 'find' the headset.  I have to keep randomly pressing the button until, by luck, the phone and headset hook up.  Very frustrating.  My brother has a cheap (~$30) that works great.  Buy plantronics.  Stay away from this.

Unreliable product, unfortunately.The on-off switch to the Bluetooth is wildly inconsistent, sometimes it will work and other times it won't. Sometimes it won't turn off no matter how many times you press the "off" switch. I put this piece of junk away and will buy a better, more reliable piece.
summary: Poor Product Not Worthy of Your Money

reviewText: Received in the condition stated in the ad and in the timeframe stated in the ad. Works perfectly with no hiccups.

I was very pleased with the quality of this product and how well it works.The quality of sound is very good as well as the microphone capabililties.It is everything that I wanted in a Bluetooth for hands on driving of my vehicle while using my cell phone.
summary: Motorola HS815 Bluetooth Meets My Expectations

reviewText: Even though this product seems a little outdated in its appearance, I have been pleased with it. It was good for the price. I use it in the vehice and when I am in my apartment. It frees up my hands to drive and also to multi-task at home. Some of the reviews complain of not hearing on it very well. That was a concern of mine when I bought it, but I haven't had much trouble with the hearing it at all. There have been only a few times. Other than that, it fits on the ear pretty well (although this is my first bluetooth product). Overall, I have been pleased.

This product's microphone doesn't pick up my voice very well, and injects a lot of hiss. The few times I've used it, I've had to switch to the handset in order for people to understand me. I'd use it if I had to make a call in the car -- where I can talk loudly and I need my hands free -- but not otherwise. This is really disappointing, since my wife has a different model Motorola headset and it's clear as a bell.

For the money this is a great buy. This is my first bluetooth headset, and I have to admit I'm hooked. My only problem is learning how to press the buttons to get the right response--connect, hold, disconnect, etc. Maybe it's me.
Works well. Wish it had a separate on/off button.  Very sensitive, can re-dail a number too easily.  Overall, very satisfied with purchase.

I allready purchesed 2 pair of hs815i believe it is a very good product for a number of reasonsi like the loop behind the ear. very easy to change left or right earhas a very loud speaker (i drive a truck you know)i find the sound quality very clear and crispy.and for the price you cant go wrong.i had some other Motorolas before but i find the HS815 the best for the money and the loudness.very good productG RISKA ONT CANADA
Reception and transmission are excellent.  It is very easy to use and is quite comfortable.  At the price purchased, the HS815 gets a big thumbs up.
summary: Easy to use and excellent performance

reviewText: i was skecptal at frist because of the price. but if u want a good ear piece thatis very easy to pair, then this is the one for u.it seems to be big but very comfortable.

The Motorola HS815 is a very simple earpiece to use.  It is comfortable.  I keep an extra one so I can talk to family on long driving trips.  I also have purchased one for my husband.  I like the capability of being able to use it on either ear.  I will purchase another one in the future.

I've been using the device for three months after I broke a Scalia headset. The device pairs quickly and easily to my RAZR V3. It is a bit difficult to get the thing on my ear at times but once it's on it stays there. The sound quality is okay, not as good as the Scalia. I've never been told in all the times I used it that I could not be heard. So I guess the microphone works well. Overall, for the price, it's a great purchase. You can spend more for others and probably get better features and reception but if you only need it while in the car or when shopping it's well worth it.

Here's the problem.  I purchased this headset to go with my SprintPCS Treo 650.  It is recognized by the Treo...mates properly.  Finally, I get one call out of it.  At the end of the call, the headset locks up and only a reboot of its firmware program by plugging it into the charger, will reset it.  All in all, it is useless for me.  I have upgraded the Treo to the latest firmware but it is no different.  Fearing a defective headset, I tried it with my wife's Motorola cell phone and it works perfectly.With tech support, one company is pointing at the other for the flaw.  I had checked the  respective sites for compatibility issues prior to purchasing the headset, but they were wrong in their reporting.  Alas, the saga continues with the heaset permanently plugged into its charger, never seeing use.The reason for the "3" rating is that I believe this to be a good headset, but the wrong match and no support for me.

I got this as a gift and it was a loyal headset and then one day it refused to take a charge. Cheaper to replace than repairing it. For the current price, less than 25 you cant go wrong in my opinion.
summary: Worked fine for 18 months or so

reviewText: This worked maybe 30 minutes before no device could connect to it, so it got thrown into my random electronics bin. Just found it, 7 years later. Wish I hadn't wasted money on it :/

This product works great with all of my bluetooth phones. If you are looking for a low cost device that provides a lot functionality this product is for you. The only negative is the size, it is larger than the newer bluetooth devices.

I bought this headset about a month ago.  After I used it for couple times, I find it lacks lots of good features.  1) It doesn't have automatically re-connect feature after the BT connection is lost with the phone.  You have to go through the hassel to reestablish the link.  2) no mute function which is a must feature for business.  3) If you put in the pocket, you could easily hit the re-dial button.Instead of this, I would highly recommend the scala-500 which is the best BT headset I have used.  Purchase from CompUSA for $10.  Much better model.

As an 'entry level' BlueTooth headset, this is a great deal.  $20-$30 bucks, built by Motorola, and it gives hands free capability! Like some other people mentioned... don't put it in your pocket unless you turn it OFF first - otherwise you'll redial the last call. I got mine used for $20 from an 'Amazon Marketplace' vendor, and am glad to try out BlueTooth with this name-brand device. I may move up to a more expensive headset in the future, but for now this covers my limited needs - it works with my Motorola RAZR, and it was cheap.

Purchased this for my husband, and he is thrilled with it! Since I have to look at it, the looks were also important to me. It is unobtrusive and yet attractive. The sound quality is excellent, and even works well in the mountains of this area, which is rather tricky at best.

The good: easy setup, lightweight, sound quality.The horrible: the ear lock flips vertically (dog ear friendly), keeps on calling people by itself which is very embarrassing.Bottom line: get the hs820 instead.
it is a great product for the money Very pleased with the unit and the people who i bought it from
summary: its a very expensive unit for a fair price

reviewText: So far this headset has worked pretty good. It took a couple of times for it to fit better on my ear. It feels loose, but it doesn't fall off. Good clarity- people can hear me and I can hear them good. Just wish ear piece could be adjustable for people with smaller ears!
When I put it at my shirt pocket,it's so easy to switch on by itself.
summary: Improve at on and off button.

reviewText: All i really have to say is that, it looks prettier than it works. it just goes to show me that i should of just spent a little more money for better quality.

Believe me, they can do better than this. The reception is not good. My friends always complain they can't hear me. I had to take off this headset and then everything is normal.Waste of money, though it is not expensive.

I bought it 2 months ago. The first week it worked pretty good. But after it went off automatically even I just took it from the charger. Plus it has a very bad design for the control button. The button is hard to control for on/off. Sometimes it's really painful to turn it on since if you push it for a little bit long, it's in discovering mode. And it can be easily turned on when it is in the pocket and redial the last phone number. Trust me, my friends are being called by it for couple times which makes me keep it out of pocket.
Worked for a very short while, but unreliable.Battery life ... about an hourHook up to device ... sometimesAmazon replaced it with a new unit, which was just as bad.I will now have to buy a new unit.

THE ON/OFF SWITCH IS VERY SENSITIVE AND TURNS ON WHEN BEING CARRIED IN CASE OR HANDBAG MAKING IT NECESSARY TO CHARGE MORE OFTEN.  THE CAR CHARGER WAS NOT COMPATIBLE WITH RAZOR MODEL 3V I HAD.  THERE WAS NO CLUE TO THIS WHEN I ORDERED IT AND HAD TO BUY AN ADDITIONAL CAR CHARGER. SEEMS OTHERWISE FINE.

This headset is very easy to use and the battery life is long for the headset (If you use it all the time, it will last all day; If you use it once or twice a day, it will last you for several days). The volume control is in a conveneient place and you can use the earpiece in either ear. The sound quality is very good when talking on the ear piece.I only have problems answering the phone with the earpiece (it won't answer the phone when I press the earpiece button), so I figured out how to set up the earpiece to automatic answer after 5 seconds (you do this by setting it up on the phone) and this function has worked very well for me.Take into consideration that I use this headset with a Motorola Phone (SLVR Pink L7) and that may be a reason why I have little trouble with this headpiece.
I hate this product.... It only lasts after one conversation.This is what I get for buying a used product- sometimes buying new is the best.
I have found the HS815 to be comfortable and reliable. And the price was fantastic!!

Básicamente el auricular es bueno, el problema es que corresponde a una generación de celulares descontinuada. El cargador vigente es el mini USB y este auricular emplea la entrada anterior de Motorola por lo que nos obliga a traer 2 cargadores portátiles y dos para el carro. Por otro lado, es bastante más grande que los de modelo reciente y algo estorboso.

I am very much satisfied with this product and your service. The delivery was as per the date and the product quality as exactly we expected. I would like to give a tag to your product and service is "Click and Get".. The Most Reliable and Trusted Online Service. Keep it up guys.. Great Job!!!ThanksSnehungsu

This headset is truly nothing special.  I've used it for just over a month, and the unit does not keep its charge for the stated time.  45 minutes is the approximate time I've experienced.  Additionally, the distance range from phone to bluetooth is far from perfect.  If you leave your phone in another room, or the signal must pass through walls, the other party on the phone cannot hear you, and the phone states "Bluetooth Signal Weak."However, when the unit is charged, and when there is not a far distance between the unit and the phone, the reception is very good.  Generally, I can hear other party very clearly, and they can hear me.  The volume can be adjusted very high, which is nice when there is background noise.The design of how the unit hooks on the ear has much to be desired.  You cannot really adjust the headset very well, as the earhook only moves in one direction -- that is, it swivels to allow use of either ear.Overall, I am certainly not thrilled with the product.  I wish I had put the money toward another, better unit.
I could hear well on this bluetooth, but people could not hear me very well (voice sounded far away, static in the background).  Finally, I had to give up and return the product.

This device hurt my ear. I was trying to replace my old set with this one, but have to return it.It is not flexible enough, so it takes a few minutes to put it on and requires both hands. Once it was on my ear started hurting. Bad, outdated product. Pay more buy somthing better
summary: Could not even get it on

reviewText: I can't complain for 15 bucks, does what it suppose to and is being very useful companion for my phone.

My first Motorola HS815 was great. I used it to record my weekly podcasts by phone. Then, my editor started noticing static and said I soundly like I was in a barrel. I don't know what happened but I assumed it was this bluetooth since I had also started experiencing static when chatting on non-recorded calls. I bought a new one of this same model. It is no better than the first one. It could be my phone, but the phone works fine (no static) when I'm not using the HS815. Just thought I would mention it in case you are planning to use this device for recorded phone calls.

I got this for a LG VX3300 to use primarily as a charger from my work desktop.  The one positive: the plug fits my phone.  Everything else... Dud.  Charging function with this phone/cable combination is not available (tried two computers, one of which I know is a powered USB port, my Palm charger works on it).  I decided to see what the data cable will do (LG doesn't advertise any data connectivity features for this phone so anything it does is a bonus).  Windows reports that it saw a device attached, identified the phone type, then said there are no drivers (win XP Pro, latest service packs).  A web search provided no matches either, nor at the phone manufacturer.  So I foolishly turned to the CDR included to redeem my purchase.  It is a hideous collection of MIDI files that are supposed to resemble songs, but I can't tell what.  I had a better collection of MIDI files 20 years ago on my Commodore 64.  This product is a total dud.I guess since the plug fits, I can cut it off and rewire it onto an old LG power cable that got rolled over by a chair.
summary: Didn't work with listed phone VX3300

reviewText: they are typical "universal" adapter kinda thing. It will hold you off if you are careful enough. I bought it because my original charger bit the dust after a year and a half. They work well... Id buy a second one if it would get me to the six month mark of getting my new cell phone. No need to spend 50 bucks for a new charger. =)

I bought this charger having lost my verizon charger thinking that it was a great deal for the price. It certainly was a great price but the outcome has been less than possitive. I have to shake the charger for a few minutes until it begins to charge the phone. After that I have to place it down very carefully lest it stop charging. Then sometimes it startes and stopes charging randomly for a while... it is very annoiying.
summary: A good idea a poor outcome

reviewText: Works great.  I love having an extra cell phone charger to keep at work.  Plus, it cost less than $5.  Can't beat the price.
Very reasonable price and sturdier than the original. Definitely suits my purpose. For an older product, it was easily available and was delivered as advertised.
I was hesitant to buy a used charger but this purchase has been well worth my money. I have not had any problems with it. It was shipped very quickly. Great buy for the money!
They sound bad and don't fit very good in your ears.Five minutes after opening these I knew I threw my money away.

I bought this headphones to go with my new A1200 with the purpose of using it as an MP3 player. But this headphones are terrible for listening music. The sound quality is not even acceptable. They do the job for phone calls, although the quality for this is barely acceptable.I'm very disappointed with this product. Don't buy it if you want it for listening music.

This pouch is beautifully tailored, the quality of the leather looks good. However, you could probably fit two razr's in this pouch. The razr is actually a very slim phone, but this pouch is a lot ticker, so there's a big empty space left in the pouch. It is supposed to be an original Motorola RAZR case so why doesn't it fit like a glove? I'm so disappointed, and for this price...? It's not worth more than 3 stars.
This is a good quality product, however it is a little big for the phone and if it gets turned upside down the magnetic snap opens and the phone falls out.

I bought this battery to replace my original and after one week of the battery running out every night I emailed the seller who promptly sent me a replacement which is just as bad as the first one. I wanted extra battery power and got the same as my old used battery.

I ordered this product not exactly sure as to the overall performance other than the obvious... to charge a phone. After trying one other product from another company with no success, I was delighted to discover that this product delivered. It has tips to fit every type of phone imaginable and it works really well. It is good to have a complete charge like when new. Actually, it was better than the one I received when new. I recommend a new battery as well, as I found this to be helpful with the new charger. Good luck.
summary: Excellent Recharger For Your Sprint Phone

reviewText: paired with two phones, no problem.  but i bought them for my PC, and was an utter fail. paired with my system (which i put together myself less than a year ago, quadcore, 4Gb RAM etc etc...more than enough).  the Win7 drivers loaded without problem. ok, great...but when i tried to use them, all i could get was choppy stutter.  and when i walked away from my unit, not even 10 feet it was cut out.  i have a bluetooth keyboard as well as mouse, and have no complaints with those.  wish i could return them....should have done more research...my own fault, not amazon's.
summary: doesn't work with my Win7 system

reviewText: Charged them up and then tested them. After using behind the head headsets for 3 years the first thing I noticed is I had  forgotten what bass sounds like. Not a serious audiophile use them mostly to watch movies late at night. Like the easy volume control. Quick start guide did not tell you to hold down the power button until it went in pairing mode but I knew that is what had to be done. Paired easily to my laptop. Like other commentators I did not receive the cord that should have been included to enable use with wired systems. Other than not receiving the cord that should have been provide no other complaints at this time. Tested them with Skype and was told my voice sounded good. Much better than the last behind the head set I paid a lot more money than I did with this pair. Don't hear the hiss other people have complained about. Not sure who to complain to try to get the wired cord I was promised. Over all better than what I expected for the price I paid.

I had some difficulty pairing the phone to my home theater pc running windows vista mce, and eventually needed to download bluetooth drivers from BlueSoleil as suggested by other users having the same difficulties. Should factor this cost in if planning to use vista mce.  Once working, the sound quality was very good, not great.  I got no hisses, buzzes, or static but the overall quality in listening to music was not as good as my wired headphones.  The headphone's metal band are also tight if your head happens to be on the larger size.Nice buy overall though.

It is great having wireless head phones but the sound quality is not to great.  The bass distorts sometimes and that really bugs me seeing as how they are"DJ" headphones.  Another down side was sometimes it would be hard to connect to my ipod or iphone. It would stop working and i would have to shut down the headphones, restart them and the blutooth on my ipod just to reconnect.  That is very frustrating when i am on the subway and my music cuts out.

Headphones are comfortable and well built.  Sound is very good with surprisingly deep bass.  Noise isolation is also very good.  Battery life is also very good.  I looked all over for a comfortable, quality bluetooth headphone and these were the winners for me.  They have performed to my expectations.

I do not understand why Motorola quit making these headphones. I am a truck driver and have had several different styles and types of bluetooth headsets and headphones from cheap to expensive. These are the best I've found. I may have had one that sounded a little better when used with the mp3 player on my phone. I may have had one that had louder call volume on both ends of the conversation although volume is by no means an issue with these. On a whole, all features combined it is by far the best especially considering it is an older model that I bought used off Amazon. When used in the environment that I do there can be no better test as to the quality of a product like this. I have noticed that when a set of these comes up for sale anywhere that they sell quickly. They are no longer manufactured by Motorola, therefore can only be found as a used item. I got lucky and the set I purchased had been barely used if it was used at all. If you plan on purchasing a product of this type, I assure you that you would not go wrong by purchasing this set of headphones. I wish they would  manufacture a product very similar to this once again. I would definitely buy one because I'm sure technology is a little better now and as compared to the other stuff I've seen out there it wouldn't take much for them to far exceed all the competition in every way, no matter what the price.

I've been using these headphones for roughly 4 months now and I really do like them.  Having said that, here are my pros/cons.Pros:-Cheap-Pairs easily with iPhone 3G-Long battery life-Comfortable (even with glasses)-Great sound-Standard mini-USB chargerCons:-Although I haven't had any problems, they do seem a little fragile so if you drop these in a back pack frequently, beware.  I have traveled internationally with them with no issues.-Not all of the controls work with the iPhone (skip/shuffle).  The volume, play/pause and answer/hangup controls work fine (which are most important anyway).  I assume these issues are more on the Apple side rather than the Motorola side.  Yeah... shocking, I know.Overall, these are a fantastic buy if you plan to use them with an iPhone!  Great price and great quality.
summary: Great headphones for the money - iPhone 3G Works!

reviewText: Update, 5/10/09: After disabling the advanced option to connect to the serial port, Bluetooth-PDA-Sync, and disabling the headset option under services, leaving only headphones configured, the sound is markedly improved, and I would recommend their use with a Leopard-configured Mac.After initial disappointment while testing it on my Macbook, I tried it on a Windows Vista PC. The difference was remarkable. On the Macbook, running Leopard 10.5.5, the sound was muffled, with poor high-frequency response. There were frequent dropouts as well, although I've not seen the kernel panic (bad news in the OS) some users have reported. On the Vista machine, I was impressed with the fidelity. The required Advanced Audio Distribution Profile (A2DP) implementation on Apple's products seems not to be mature yet, for some reason. It's still missing from the iPhone, at this point.Bottom line: the quality of your experience with this headset largely depends on the hardware and operating system with which you will use it. On Vista, XP with third party software, and most newer mobile phones, you'll probably have a good experience. Should work on Linux as well. On a Mac, you may not like it.
these are a great buy for the price I got mine for $40 and have had them for 3 years now.

I bought these to match my iPod touch and get those annoying earbuds out of my auditory canals.  Headphones arrived with DOA charger, but seller replaced that immediately and all was well.  Headphones are apparently designed to work with a Motorolla cell phone and many of the features do not work with iPod Touch.  Volume control does work, no problem synching with iPod Touch, and battery life has so far been good.  No need to spend big bucks on Bluetooth headphones when limiting factor for sound quality may be compressed mp3 files or iPod itself.  I consider these headphones to be a good value.
summary: Good value - works with iPod Touch

reviewText: I purchased these for my laptop which has a defective headphone jack & for use with my ipod's bluetooth adapter (wRevo A100). After a software update to my laptop's adapter I could not be happier with the purchase. As soon as I turn on my laptop, the headphones connect. The sound quality is great and I can easily walk 15-20 feet away with line of sight and not experience distortion. If I go into another room, there will be a drop off, but it reconnects once line of sight is re-established.With the ipod bluetooth adapter, all of the features work: volume control, play/pause & song forward/backward. Worth noting that the forward/backward track function does not work with iTunes.They do get slightly uncomfortable after about 4 hours of straight wear, but after 15 minutes of rest, I'm good to go for another several hours.I have not tried them as headset for my phone, because I don't use them for that, so no review on the microphone.I would not use them for jogging or any exercise due to how that would feel bouncing on the ears, but they stay on really well as I mow the lawn and do other yard work for 2-3 hours.
Product does an excellent job as a phone and musical headphones.  My biggest issue and problem was linking the unit to my iPod via the motorola bluetooth adapter.

I had difficulty finding any info on the new iPhone 3.0 release that included Stereo Bluetooth in the update.  I purchased these headphones thinking, well if they don't pair then I'm only out $30.  They arrived, they paired easily and the sound quality is great.  These are great headphones and the microphone is even good quality when you switch from music to take a call.  Highly recommended for anyone with an iPhone.
summary: Works seamlessly with the new iPhone 3.0 update

reviewText: the head set works great but the fact that all the controls are on your head while you are trying to adjust them took a little getting used too.  Guess there is no other way to do it.
summary: works, controls take a little while to figure out

reviewText: I purchased these headphones with the intention of using them with my Iphone.  They are not compatible.  They work fine with my computer.  The sound quality is also not so great.  In all I guess they get the job done but I wish I would have done a but more research.
summary: Ok but not what I expected

reviewText: These headphones worked great for me -- I could play music, games, etc with my laptop or phone.  Then after about a half dozen uses or so, they just stopped showing up on Bluetooth scans.  I checked that they were charged up and pushed the button to make them discoverable, but no luck.Maybe I just got a bad unit, but this purchase was a disappointment for me.  If these headphones had continued to work properly I'd recommend them, but as it is I just can't.

Purchased these from Shopcell through Amazon. They did not include the audio cable as advertised in other sites. They did include the charger. After installing a IOGear microtransmitter in the USB of my laptop, the headset was recognized but did not play any audio. I found out through research that Microsoft XP was somewhat lacking in its support for USB audio. I had to go to the IOGear sight and download the Broadcom drivers for the Bluetooth transmitter. These drivers capture the audio from the PC and put it on the USB bus. After installing the Broadcom drivers, everything worked as advertised. I think that Vista has the necessary drivers  but am not sure. Sound quality is not bad for the price. THe users manual is online at Motorola.

I bought these because I thought they would be closed, meaning that music you listen would not be heard from the outside.  This was important to me because I do not like to disturb those around me, also I like the 'privacy'.  As big and padded as they are, they aren't closed. As for sound, the music sounded crisp- although I admit I didn't give it a thorough listen.  I have an average sized head and the fit was pretty snug. My Sennheiser HD 202's oval shaped muffs are much more soft and comfortable, the circular shape of the S805's put pressure against some parts of the ear (unless you have circular ears!).  The headphones seem very sturdy and well made. It was easy to pair with my Samsung Propel. Pretty good, but these will be going back.

I bought this to go with my MP3 Player, so I can listen to music in hotel rooms when traveling without having to hear the AC units running, and I have to say it is amazing. I used it on Saturday when cutting the grass and it was great, does everything except pause/skip tracks. Turns out it is my BT transmitter causing the issues there. The headphones are well made, come in a very nice case which can store the charger and maybe even an MP3 too.For some reason mine was missing the 2.5-3.5mm cable, which is annoying as I was planning on using it on the plane. I've contacted the seller and I am sure they will take care of it for me.The best part of these headphones is they are super comfortable. I have worn them for about four hours outside in 90F weather and were not a bit of trouble. Well worth the money and more than five stars.

I got this headphones because of the cheaper price, and you get what you pay for. It does work, but sounds is noticeably worse than any wired headphones, controls are not very well designed, connection with my computer gets interrupted for no reason every so often.

I bought these headphones to use with my Palm Pre and it's been working just fine despite these headphones having been designed for Motorola phones only. I've had no issues with any of the features.The headphones feel tight around the head, but that's good. They're nice and snug. I have a pretty big head and I don't even have these headphones extended all the way out (whereas on my old headphones I had to use the longest extension).The "sound canceling" is misleading because the headphones don't actually have any noise canceling like Bose headphones do, but I guess the snugness of the ear piece is what is referred to as "sound canceling" here. I think it's the wrong term to use because obviously a lot of sound leaks through, but the headphones do a decent job of blocking some of it out.What disappointing is that there's no standard input jack, only one of those skinny phone inputs. So, you can't just plug them directly with a regular cable.I haven't had any battery life issues, but I've never had them on for more than 8 hours. They seem to recharge very quickly too.Call quality is great. I wish I could turn up the volume up ever more at times though. Some of my callers who like to whisper are hard to hear.The "one click" redial button is very convenient. Just press the "Call" button for 2 seconds and it will automatically dial your last-used contact. Very cool.Build quality seems very sturdy. The little flap that covers the inputs is awful though. I estimate that it will break within a matter of months, but the headphones themselves feel very good.Overall, the fact that it's Bluetooth compatible is worth the $30 alone. Most other full DJ-style headphones start at least $80. Even if these headphones aren't for you, the next-to-nothing price is well worth the value. That's main reason I got these - they're so cheap!
great item and you can get the receiver for the ipod at radioshack for 10.00 dollars.

Overall I really like these headphones. I have had them for about a year and a half now and they are reaching the end of their life cycle. Phones are really only designed to last about a year and these use a battery based on a mobile phone's battery so it is getting to the point where it doesn't hold much of a charge anymore.They are quite functional if not occasionally finicky with the signal. I have never had a problem getting them to pair with a phone but getting them to work with Windows XP, Vista or 7 is flaky at best. Windows 7 is much better but it is still pretty hit and miss. I don't think it is the headphones, though.The controls are good if basic - answer phone/on/off, pause, volume up/down, skip forward/back. They are quite intuitive once you get accustomed to where they are. I would say the dial style control for the volume and track skip is easier to use than buttons.The volume is fine but not deafening. I found myself looking for more volume than was available in situations like a noisy bus ride or mowing the lawn. That said, the noise isolation is quite good but they could have given the speakers more punch.The leather ear pads are quite comfortable. I often use my headphones while exercising and for all types of activities. The problem with using them while exercising is it makes my ears sweaty but the headphones aren't at fault there.A really nice feature which is unusual for Bluetooth headsets is you can use these as regular headphones. You need a 2.5mm headphone jack to plug into the headphones, and a cord connected to a 3.5mm jack to plug into your source. I don't think this comes stock but I find it baffling why they wouldn't include it as they bothered to design it that way but then they don't include a little cord to facilitate that. It is handy when the battery runs out, you can still connect to many devices. The quality when they are plugged in is much better.The integrated microphone is another nice feature although people did mention it wasn't super clear on the phone calls where I was using it. You can also use it with programs like Skype if you can configure your computer to handle it properly. It would be nice if you could use the microphone as a plug in microphone like you can with the headphones.With so many great features it is a shame they didn't pay more attention to quality in other areas such the design and strength of plastic. The swivel area is built to fail as the design is too tight and the plastic is brittle. The lay flat design should have been a feature but it compromises the structure of the headphones. One of the reasons why I got these is because they lay flat, so I could transport them in my backpack. I don't recommend this at all as they are not built tough enough for being jostled around. At this stage they are held together completely by crazy glue and they keep breaking in different places so the original plastic is being gradually replaced like crazy glue fossilization.If you like wearing things that light up (I don't) you will be pleased that these come with flashing lights. These can be turned off by holding down the buttons on both sides simultaneously for two seconds. You have to do it every time you turn the headphones on.On the next version of this product I would like to see: better quality construction, a search function as well as a skip function, make the volume controls work when they are plugged in as conventional headphones, allow for the microphone to work if plugged in and a replaceable battery, like is standard in a mobile phone.I would recommend this if you don't intend on being too rough on them, like if you just want to use them at home and if you don't expect more than a year's use out of them. They are brilliant for what they do and they have some features that make them stand out from the competition but the poor construction makes it difficult for me to truly recommend them.

Over all I gave it 3 stars due to audio quality only, but would have given it 3.5 stars if Amazon would let me.  :)  I'm sure there are those here who will say its a good mid-ranged headset, but as far as quality sound goes its about a 6.5 out of 10 for me.  Everything else is great, and it works flawlessly to me.  It just doesn't handle volume or bass too well, so it only gets so loud without distortion setting in.  Because of that I would have thought it pricey, but it is well made, sturdy, and functions as it should (bluetooth).  I have some 5yr old $20.00 DJ styled sony headphone that will blow the sound of these clear AWAY!!  This device is good for travel, gym, eh.. maybe thats it.  I wish my sony's were bluetooth enabled.  :(

I got these headphones for working out, and for that they do fine. There is a little feedback some of the time which is rarely frustrating, but when it is frustrating. I try and remember I only paid $30 for Bluetooth headphones. These headphones aren't the highest quality, and definately don't get as loud as I would want, but for the price they are about as good as possible. This product syncs easily with iPhone 3gs.

I've had mine now since March 2007.  Sound quality is very good at reasonable volumes and I love the controls.  Battery longevity is phenomenal!  Main problem is the plastic half-rings that hold the earpieces tend to break, especially if you fall asleep while wearing these.  If they break then _don't_use_super-glue_.  There is so much leverage on the weak spots that super-glue has no chance to hold it together.Here's what I've found that finally works after three tries fixing these things:Each half-ring is shaped like a trough with internal dividers.  Rough up the insides of the trough with sandpaper, especially the box-shaped space right under the "pivot"  -- I used a dremel carefully with a fine ball-shaped cutter (just rough the surface; don't remove too much plastic.)  While doing this don't touch any of the mating surfaces where the broken pieces join.If there are any cracks that did not break through completely then drill out the end of each crack to keep it from growing longer using the finest drill bit you have (I used the dremel here again) .  Use ABS cement from the hardware store to glue the broken pieces together: cover the mating surfaces completely with a _thin_ coat of ABS cement; hold the pieces together for a couple minutes; then let the glue set for at least an hour.  (Super-glue will _not_ hold!)Now fill the "trough" with a mixed two-part epoxy (resin+hardener; follow the directions that come with the epoxy) -- this is what you roughed-up the surfaces for.  If you leave the surfaces "shiny" it may seem to stick, but it will break again in a few days.  Let the epoxy cure for 48 hours.Reassemble and enjoy!If I had it to do all over again I'd fill it with epoxy _before_ it broke.Hope this helps!-- J.
summary: Nice, but fragile.  Plastic repair instructions.

reviewText: I have to say that I was a bit skeptical about buying a BT headset. Every one I looked at was either too expensive or looked too cheap. The Motorola S805 performs at the highest quality for BT headphones. The sound quality is not on par with high end headphones but is on par with most mid ranged wired headphones. The bass is not too faint and the treble is not over powering, it seems to have the right amount of each. The wonderful thing is that it synced right up with my BT dongle for my computer and I now can watch movies and listen to music without being wired to the stupid laptop. I have to say that these are some of the best headphones that I have owned.One Week Later: I have to tell you that I love these headphones. The sound is richer than I first thought. I have owned Bose headphones and I have to tell you these are comperable and the battery has lasted me over 12 hours of play time and still going strong, at a moderate to high level of volume. These head phone are well worth the money!!

These phones are really a bargain. They sound quite good - a bit hot in the treble area, but that's a plus for these ears that have lost a bit on top. The fit is snug but comfortable for my average size head. They might be a bit tight for someone requiring a large hat! They were easy to set up with my iphone. Pairing was easy. I noticed a few complaints in that area. The trick is to open the settings and have the bluetooth preference showing when you pair. Not as slick as some devices, but not that big a deal. While not audiophile, they sound a hell of a lot better than a couple of $100, in-ear units that I have. The only disappointment is that I couldn't get them working as plain vanilla wireless phones with my laptop. I succeeded in pairing them but was not able to hear audio from a CD or DVD. I'm not sure if they should work in that mode and the bare-bone instructions aren't much help. But for $35.00 it's pretty hard to fault them.

When I found out my wife was pregnant, I instantly looked to acquire a set of headphones that I could use so as not to disturb the sleeping baby. I had already purchased theMotorola MOTOROKR S9 Bluetooth Stereo Headphones, but those didn't work well when laying down, and they didn't do so great with blocking outside noises. I also had theSony MDR-RF925RK 900 MHz Analog RF Wireless Headphone, which were good at canceling outside noises, but produced so much static and whitenoise that they were useless.When I came across the S805 I went ahead and gave them a try. I'm glad I did. First, note that I would never use these to make phone calls. They can, but they are so big and bulky that I wouldn't even try. Walking around the house with these giant beasts isn't my idea of a good bluetooth talking device. What I use them for is to watch movies/anime and play the PS3.They are hooked up to my Yamaha HTR-5640 Home Theater Receiver using aSony Bluetooth Transmitter and Adapter for iPod and MP3 Players. Unless your receiver has Bluetooth built in, you'll need a transmitter. Just be sure it supports A2DP. I had theJabra Bluetooth Music Adaptor, but it didn't work with the S805 because it wasn't A2DP compliant.Overall, I love the quality of the connection: no whitenoise, no static. There is the occasional dropped signal, but that's easily and quickly restored. I purchased these in December of 2008, and in March of 2011 they still work like a charm.

First of all, What is the category 'Does not work'? How many stars do you give that?  If the item is awesome, is that one star for 'does not work' or five?  That is really a worthless topic.  Five stars either means it doesn't work 'real good' or it doesn't work 'real bad'.  You have to figure it out I guess.Now, this headset is the shizzle!  It does have a bit of re-connection annoyance, but after figuring this out, the headset is awesome!  I changed pandora to the high quality streams and these things were more than adequate (actually probably way more than appropriate) for quality and volume.The bluetooth is perfect, allowing me to play the tunes from my PC while able to hear emails and take phone calls from my cell over bluetooth.The only problem with them (and not really the device's fault) and why it didn't earn five stars is...These aren't really the 'new' unit.  These are 'new in bulk' and do not include the audio cable, case or retail box that an new device would.  The inclusion of the audio cable (along with the price) drove me to purchase these.  Well, they didn't come with the audio cable and I have not found one anywhere.  The plug is not common, so no standard cable.Other than that, these rock!  Highly guaranteed!
summary: The total shizzle for the bucks!

reviewText: Works great for music but should not use in car as it covers both ears.  Very sturdy.  My bride loves using it during her workouts and around the house.If you have someone that is hard to hear on the phone, this is the cure!  Great value for the price!
The product is bulky, easy to sink, works well with the iphone, simple controls.  If not so bulky I would have given this product a higher rating.

Overall: This product works great.  I'm quite satisfied with the quality and performance.  The sound quality is high.Pros:-I'm very satisfied with battery life.  I left it on (accidentally) for 2 days on standy and I still got several hours of use out of them without a recharge.-The sound quality is excellent.-The noise-canceling is excellent to the point where my wife hates me having them on because I can't hear her (that could be either a pro OR con depending on how you look at it).-Call quality is great -- both on the headphone and microphone side.  People on the other end have no problems hearing me.-If I'm listening to music via the analog jack from my sound card, and I get a call on my cell phone, the headset automatically switches over when I answer the call, and automatically switches back to the music when the call is over.Cons:-I have a slightly bigger head that some people I suppose, and these headphones feel tight to me.  Because of this, my ears begin to get sore after about an hour of use.-The supplied audio cable is only 2-3 feet long-There is no analog microphone jack to use this set with non-bluetooth devices like my desktop computer. This is remedied by a cheap usb BT adapter, but would have been an easy feature for Motorola to implement.-Battery takes about 4 hours to charge fully, and is not charged on purchase. If you buy these, be willing to wait for 4 hours once you unbox them to try them out-Headphones are not operable during recharging
I love my d.j style headphones. But they didn't come with the cord to charge them. How can I recharge them when it doesn't have a charging cord.

Overall, its a good set of headphones. Ive owned quite a few sets of bt headphones and by far i still dont think any are better than the Moto HT 820 setThe jog dials are good and handy, and they are comfy on the ears. they already send you the case with them too so dont buy it optional. They wont tell you this when ordering hoping that you will pitch them more money...They are also a little on the large side. If you purchase you will get cracked on for looking like DJ Khaled( Just giving heads up. the ht 820's that moto makes are the best ive ever owned. above any.But for the money these a great fit ....enjoy

Well, I think these are the fines headphones that I have ever own, and I have owned plenty. Let me explain. I have a TMOBILE dash and I have a blue tooth adapter for my home stereo. So I just wanted a pair of headphones for my home stero. Well what I recieved was so much more. Now I pair these headphones to my home stereo and my phone! How cool is that.(Now mind you I did not expect all these fetures) So While I am watching TV or plaing video games through my headphone, if my phone rings it will automatically switch over to my phone! And all I do is talk. Its cool! Then once its done, it switches back. The headphones also allow you to control music from you phone(iif your phone supports it) as far as track forward, backward  and volume. There are a host of other feature, but I did not read the manual. Also there is a jack on your headphone where you can plug up a cord to make them corded headphone. Its so cool. They charge via USB and they come with a nifty carrying case. If you are looking for an affordable pair of headphones with alot of versatility, then these are for you(Just dont excercise with these because they with cause your ears to sweat alot, they are not made for excerciseing!)

Got these to use with my PC because of cumbersome cords.  Connected easily and all functions work perfectly. Audio quality is excellent, much better than anticipated.  Controls are easy to use and very well designed.  They are a little heavy, but still comfortable (and I have larger ears and wear glasses) and stay in place well while moving.  At this price I didn't expect great quality, but these are very sturdy. I'm very pleased with the combination of a quality product and great price.

I have a T-mobile Sidekick, and found the headphone jack is in an awkward location, as most holsters cover up the hole. So I went on a quest to find some bluetooth stereo headphones. After looking at the more expensive (about twice the cost) Sony headphones, I found these ones by Motorola. I was concerned that they would not be compatible with my phone, but they paired up seamlessly. I was also surprised at the level of control the headphones give you, enabling you to adjust the volume, move back and forth between tracks, pause and play, etc. - and all of this works fine with my phone, even when my phone shuts off the screen to conserve battery.Speaking of batteries, I charged the headphones for a couple of hours when I first got them. I believe I've had them for about 10 days now, and have used them extensively, and they still have a charge and are working just fine.As far as range/quality, I'm highly impressed at the quality of sound these headphones produce, and am pleased at the volume level they can generate.Apparently, you can use the headphones for calls also, as they also have a built-in microphone, but I have yet to test this function so cannot comment on it (sorry!)In all, I highly recommend these headphones and I'm very satisfied with my purchase :)

I did a little research before buying and decide to try these because of the price, style, and good reviews.  I am so pleased that I decided to write my own review.  Yes, it took more than 4 hours to charge.  I haven't had it long but the battery seems fine.  I thought I had it charging at work. At lunch I disconnected it and threw it in my gym bag.  I left work early and when I try to turn it on it wouldn't.  When I got home I charged it and today it worked fine.  Not sure if that was my error or not.  The sound is very good and it does a fair job in blocking out surrounding noise.  I read in another review that someone had bad quality sound when using his computer but great sound with his mobile device.  Well on my computer the bluetooth gave me an option of using my headphones as "headphones" or "headset".  With the headset option the sound was poor but in headphone option it was perfect.  I think headset is for voice conversations via internet and headphones is for listening to music.  I was at the gym on one of the cardio machines when I received a call.  Quality was very good on my end, the other end made no complaints.  Took them to the gym twice now and had no issues with them staying on.  I do wear them outside my hoodie.  I like the controls but with the iPhone you can't use the track control.  You can use the volume, play/pause, and of coarse talk buttons.  The signal did cut out a few times but I think it could be the surroundings.  On the bus and at the gym, no problem.  Walking outside, it cuts out.  Seemed worse in downtown. I read this issue with other bluetooth headphones so it may not be the product but the technology. Paring was no problem, but I ran into some issues when it was paired to two devices.  My computer refused to disconnect to allow the phone to connect the headphones.  I had to turnoff the bluetooth on my computer completely and pair my mobile again.The price is good and it seems durable and well made.  I am very pleased with my purchase thus far.

I was a little skeptical at first because of some of the reviews I read. However knowing the sound quality of Motorola HT820 I said I would give it a shot and to my surprise I love it. I actually like these better than the HT820. The sound is crisp and the acoustics of it is that of high quality Sony headphones. The only con's I have is that they are big. The picture made me think that they were a lot smaller but never the less I sleep in them and go to the gym, and even run with them on. They fit tightly and are adjustable with a good solid build. Battery life is excellent it works perfect with my Blackberry Storm, and my IPod touch with the 3.0 update of course however the skype buttons are useless for the Ipod but works great on the Blackberry. As far as using them for answering calls is cool, but I don't recommend it only because you will find yourself talking very loud because the cushions on the ear phones does such a good job of cancelling out noise.

I've really enjoyed being able to listen to music wires-free. The padding on them makes them very comfortable, something my other headphones lack on the part that goes over the head. And it's great to be able to control volume, pause/play, and skip through songs right from the headphones.The pairing has been a bit confusing for me, though. I've had some trouble trying to get it into paring mode. It's had to figure out what mode it's in from the blinking light. I haven't been able to get it to pair with both my phone and my iPod's adapter. Either one of those works, though.I haven't tested out the battery life in full, but it's lasted through 2 hours without having a problem.It would also be nice to be able to use them while they are charging.

This is my first pair of Bluetooth headphones, and I opted for this style because I want a set of headphones for my phone that will truly deliver the music quality and sound that I'm looking for, and I want that to come in a pair of headphones that feel like they're worth the money I paid for them. These headphones easily fulfill both of these desires for me, and then some!These Motorola headphones are NOT lightweight, but they also won't have you feeling overly weighed down, either. They're simply solid-feeling in weight and construction. I read many other reviews of these online, one from an owner who has owned these headphones over the course of at least a year and a half, and who paid over $120.00 for his pair. Considering the price that I got these for (comparable to the prices that I found for these here on Amazon), I feel like I got mine at a steal, at less than $40.00!These Motorola headphones FEEL like they're worth $150.00, and the stereo sound that comes from them is great. The sound is crisp, clear, and has plenty of depth to it for my taste. I didn't find these headphones to be lacking in their production of bass. No, the bass in these ISN'T going to blow your eardrums out, but I like to have all of the sound elements enhance the overall effect of the music, not overpower it.As far as taking calls on these go, there is no obvious microphone on these, but they work great, just the same. My callers had no problems whatsoever hearing me on these, and I could hear them beautifully on them as well. I was told that the audio being received from these was loud, crisp, and clear, and the same seemed to be the case for me as well on the other end of the calls. I've also had no trouble using the operational buttons, and my phone found and paired with these headphones easily. The only thing that I didn't remember when I ordered these, though (completely my own fault), is that I won't be able to wear these to take calls while I'm driving, as traffic laws dictate that both ears cannot be covered and obstruct vital traffic sounds.
